title: Chapter I Water Sources and Supply
items.abstract: <jats:p>Water is one of the most important engineering materials used by industry. Without an adequate supply of water of acceptable quality virtually no industry can exist. In a very real sense man's industrial progress can be traced by charting his utilization of the water resources of the earth. Our future industrial progress will depend in large measure on our rational use of water.</jats:p>

title: LABORATORY SUPPLY CENTER
Part 3 Laboratory Supply Dealers
ALTERNATIVES IN WATER SUPPLY
items.abstract: <jats:p>As America's water needs and problems become more complex, more complex methods for coping with them must be assessed. A hierarchy of water quality is proposed as one of many possible changes in water supply practice, a hierarchy which would lessen the need to squander expensive, finely treated waters on rough usage.</jats:p>

title: Single-dose eyedrops (March 28, p. 25): supply of minims
items.abstract: <jats:p>We have learnt that the eleven varieties of Minims (Smith & Nephew Pharmaceuticals) which we listed are no longer made. The makers plan to introduce a much improved form of Minims later this year.</jats:p>

title: A MODEL OF PIG SUPPLY*, †
items.abstract: <jats:p>Considerable fluctuationd in size have characterised the pig industry in Northern Ireland during the past decade. What are the causes of these fluctuations? Can they be reduced? Or, can they be anticipated and planned for ? These questions form the point of departure for this analysis. The answers are sought by hypothesising and testing an econometric model of the supply side of the pig industry. The estimated model is then used in the analsis of some of the problems of the industry.</jats:p>

Project Atlantis: A Design of the Nuclear Power Supply for an Undersea City
items.abstract:
<jats:sec>
                  <jats:title>Abstract.</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>In order to provide the power necessary to sustain a city of 20,000 people 600 feet below the surface of the ocean, it is proposed to use four nuclear power plants. Each of the 500 Mwth, gas cooled, uranium-thorium fueled, thermal reactor. The power requirements for the city include oxygen production, carbon dioxide removal, and fresh water production, as well as electrical power and heating. A 100% overload has been allowed for industrial and agricultural applications.</jats:p>
                  <jats:sec>
                     <jats:title>Authors' Note.</jats:title>
                     <jats:p>Project Atlantis was a six semester hour design course for graduate students in the Nuclear Engineering Program of the Mechanical Engineering Department of the University of Texas at Austin. The following paper represents a synopsis of the final report presented by the six graduate students to their advisors.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>"In one day and one night of unprecedented upheaval, with earthquakes and floods like none ever witnessed by man before, the entire army of Athens was swallowed up by the earth, and simultaneously the whole island of Atlantis disappeared utterly beneath the waves of the Ocean."Plato's Dialogue "TIMAEUS"c. 400 B.C.SCOPE OF DESIGN</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>The goal of this project was to design a nuclear power plant system which would furnish the complete power requirements for a city of 20,000 people located under the ocean on the continental shelf of the united States. The continental shelf is usually defined as that portion of the U.S. coastline with an ocean depth of 600 feet or less. At the maximum depth the city would be subjected to a pressure of 275 psia and an ambient water temperature of about 40°F.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>In order to move freely between the city and the ocean floor it will be necessary to maintain the living and working quarters of the city at ambient pressure. To prevent nitrogen narcosis, the inhabitants of the city will breathe a mixture of helium, nitrogen, and oxygen. Because of the higher thermal conductivity of the helium, it will be necessary to maintain an ambient temperature in the city of about 80° F to insure "shirt-s leeve" comfort. Other special environmental considerations are:Use of water for neutron and gamma-ray shielding.contamination of seawater by neutron activation or fission product release.Use of seawater as a low temperature sink for heat rejection.Flooding of the reactor core.The corrosive nature of seawater.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>The power required from the reactor has been determined as follows (see Fig. 1):Air conditioningventilation-2000 ft 3 /hrperson, 1 Mwe.CO2 removal-IOO watts/ person by electrodialysis, 2 Mwe.O2 makeup-2 Ibs/personday by electrolysis, 6 Mwe.Non-industrial electrical: lighting, communications, entertainment, etc.-35Mwe.Industrial electrical 175 Mwe.Fresh water production 130 Mwth.Heating-240 Mwth.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>The choice of a nuclear reactor to provide this power was made in order to satisfy the requirements of reliability and independence from surface supply lines.</jats:p>
                     <jats:p>Supplied with sufficient power, air, and water, the city represents a permanent, self-sufficient, undersea habitation. The most probable use of such a city, in the near future, would be to support rotating teams of scientific and technical personnel conducting advanced and extended experiments.</jats:p>
                  </jats:sec>
               </jats:sec>

Soil Water Supply and Depletion Pattern Differentiate among Zea, mays L. Single‐ and Double‐Cross Hybrids<sup>1</sup>
items.abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The relationship of irrigation response of several double‐ and singe‐cross <jats:italic>Zea mays</jats:italic> L. hybrids to inbred line composition and effectiveness in supplying the plant water requirements from the soil water supply was investigated. An experiment involving 25 double‐cross hybrids showed that 16 of these hybrids gave a 10% or greater grain yield response to irrigation, whereas the remainder showed very little or no yield increase. Certain hybrids produced about as well without irrigation as the highest yielding irrigation‐responsive hybrids. Subsequent experiments examined the irrigation response of several single‐cross hybrids and their double‐cross products. In a season of severe drouth requiring major irrigation, yield response of the double‐cross products to irrigation was predicted very well by averaging the yield response of the four non‐parental single crosses of the four inbreds involved.</jats:p><jats:p>Examination of the soil water depletion pattern of single‐cross hybrids has shown that the yields are related to the capability of the plant to meet its water requirements during the critical fruiting period from existing soil water supply. Cited as examples are the cytoplasmic male‐sterile versions of several single crosses which rather consistently yield better than their fertile counterparts.</jats:p>
